title: 109_hr5933
content: The "Business Travel Facilitation Act of 2006" may be cited as the Business Travel Facilitation Act. This Act pertains to business facilitation visitors. Section 214 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include business facilitation visitors, defined as aliens visiting the US temporarily to provide services. Aliens visiting the US temporarily as business facilitation visitors must meet certain conditions, including providing services under a qualifying services contract or receiving management or technical training from a US entity. Aliens visiting the US as business facilitation visitors must meet specific conditions, including being nationals of countries certified by the Secretary of Homeland Security for combating visa fraud through measures like machine-readable passports and biometric technology. Aliens visiting the US for business purposes must meet conditions such as having machine-readable passports and biometric technology. The consular officer must verify that these conditions have been met for visa approval. Services provided must also meet specific conditions. Aliens providing services in the US must have all expenses covered by their employer and possess expert knowledge of the entity's technology or operations. Aliens providing services in the US must have expert knowledge of the entity's technology or operations and all required licenses. The alien must have expert knowledge and required licenses to provide services in the US. For management or technical training, the alien must be an employee of a firm affiliated with a US entity providing the training. The alien must have expert knowledge and required licenses to provide services in the US, and for management or technical training, they must be affiliated with a US entity through a joint venture, purchase of goods/services, or sales. The alien must have expert knowledge and required licenses to provide services in the US, and for management training, they must have at least 5 years of related experience. The alien must have at least 5 years of experience directly related to management or management training and detailed knowledge of their employer's business operations to receive management training. The alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing professional services may stay for up to 1 year, with a possible 6-month extension granted by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security can grant a single 6-month extension to an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing professional services if there is an unforeseen delay in completing the services described in the contract and replacing the alien would further delay fulfillment of the contract terms. The Secretary of Homeland Security can grant a single 6-month extension to an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing professional services if there is an unforeseen delay in completing the services described in the contract. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prohibit nationals of a country from admission to the United States if they have engaged in a pattern of fraud involving visa applications or other immigration matters. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prohibit nationals from admission to the United States for engaging in fraudulent activities related to visa applications or immigration matters. Additionally, the Secretary may also prohibit nationals from entering the US as business facilitation visitors for a specified period based on a qualifying services contract between a foreign provider of professional services and a US entity. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prohibit nationals from entering the US based on a qualifying services contract between a foreign provider of professional services and a US entity, specifying the time period, duties, remuneration, and working conditions for the alien. The US entity must provide the alien with working conditions comparable to those of similarly situated providers of professional services and the alien must possess the necessary credentials to provide the services covered by the contract. The contract must include licenses and authorizations for services in the US, as well as the foreign provider's responsibilities for the alien's compliance with admission terms and return to their home country.
